Class Geodesy

java.lang.Object
org.jscience.earth.geodesy.Geodesy
public class Geodesy extends Object
Geodetic calculations for Earth science.

Provides:

  • Haversine formula for great-circle distance
  • Vincenty formula for high-accuracy geodesic distance
  • Bearing calculations
  • Destination point given bearing and distance

* @author Silvere Martin-Michiellot
Since:
1.0
Author:
Gemini AI (Google DeepMind)

  • Method Details

    • haversineDistance

      public static Quantity<Length> haversineDistance(double lat1, double lon1, double lat2, double lon2)
      Haversine formula for great-circle distance. Simple and fast, accuracy ~0.5%
      Parameters:
      lat1 - latitude of point 1 (degrees)
      lon1 - longitude of point 1 (degrees)
      lat2 - latitude of point 2 (degrees)
      lon2 - longitude of point 2 (degrees)
      Returns:
      distance as Quantity

    • vincentyDistance

      public static Quantity<Length> vincentyDistance(double lat1, double lon1, double lat2, double lon2)
      Vincenty formula for geodesic distance on ellipsoid. High accuracy (~0.5mm), but may fail for near-antipodal points.

    • initialBearing

      public static double initialBearing(double lat1, double lon1, double lat2, double lon2)
      Initial bearing from point 1 to point 2.
      Returns:
      bearing in degrees (0-360)

    • destination

      public static double[] destination(double lat, double lon, double bearingDegrees, double distanceM)
      Destination point given start, bearing, and distance.
      Parameters:
      lat - starting latitude (degrees)
      lon - starting longitude (degrees)
      bearingDegrees - initial bearing (degrees)
      distanceM - distance in meters
      Returns:
      [lat, lon] of destination

    • midpoint

      public static double[] midpoint(double lat1, double lon1, double lat2, double lon2)
      Midpoint between two coordinates.

    • pressureRatio

      public static double pressureRatio(double altitudeM)
      Barometric formula for atmospheric pressure at altitude. P = P0 * exp(-Mgh/RT)
      Parameters:
      altitudeM - altitude in meters
      Returns:
      pressure ratio P/P0
